articles.headline: With BRICS Invite, Iran Shrugs Off Outcast Status in the West
articles.snippet: The invitation came after a tumultuous year of domestic unrest and economic gloom, and follows a pivot by the country toward Russia and China.
articles.abstract: The invitation came after a tumultuous year of domestic unrest and economic gloom, and follows a pivot by the country toward Russia and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past 12 months, Iran has lurched from crisis to crisis.

articles.headline: Instacart Reveals $428 Million in Profit but Slowing Growth Ahead of I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Nearly 30 percent of Instacart’s revenue came from advertising, and grocery orders were flat in the first half of this year, the company said.
articles.abstract: Nearly 30 percent of Instacart’s revenue came from advertising, and grocery orders were flat in the first half of this year, the company said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Instacart, the grocery delivery business that boomed during the pandemic, took a step on Friday toward an initial public offering that will be a test of Wall Street’s appetite for tech start-ups after a yearlong industry slump.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: The Silicon Valley Elite Who Want to Build a City From Scratch
articles.snippet: A mysterious company has spent $800 million in an effort to buy thousands of acres of San Francisco Bay Area land. The people behind the deals are said to be a who’s who of the tech industry.
articles.abstract: A mysterious company has spent $800 million in an effort to buy thousands of acres of San Francisco Bay Area land. The people behind the deals are said to be a who’s who of the tech industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2017, Michael Moritz, the billionaire venture capitalist, sent a note to a potential investor about what he described as an unusual opportunity: a chance to invest in the creation of a new California city.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Raimondo Heads to China to Both Promote Trade, and Restrict It
articles.snippet: The commerce secretary’s trip may be the clearest demonstration yet of the balancing act the Biden administration is trying to pull off in its relations with China.
articles.abstract: The commerce secretary’s trip may be the clearest demonstration yet of the balancing act the Biden administration is trying to pull off in its relations with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, is heading to China on Saturday with two seemingly contradictory responsibilities: a mandate to strengthen U.S. business relations with Beijing while also imposing some of the toughest Chinese trade restrictions in years.

articles.headline: Ukraine Is Still Grappling With the Battlefield Prigozhin Left Behind
articles.snippet: He shored up Russian forces at their most vulnerable and drew Ukraine into a costly fight for Bakhmut, giving Moscow time to build defenses that are slowing Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
articles.abstract: He shored up Russian forces at their most vulnerable and drew Ukraine into a costly fight for Bakhmut, giving Moscow time to build defenses that are slowing Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Russian military reeled on the battlefield in Ukraine last autumn, a foul-mouthed ex-convict with a personal connection to President Vladimir V. Putin stepped out of the shadows to help.

articles.headline: In Push to Modernize Cairo, Cultural Gems and Green Spaces Razed
articles.snippet: The Egyptian government has demolished historic tombs, cultural centers, artisan workshops and gardens in pursuit of large-scale urban renewal.
articles.abstract: The Egyptian government has demolished historic tombs, cultural centers, artisan workshops and gardens in pursuit of large-scale urban renewal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ancient tombs have been shattered. Gardens have vanished, and with them many of Cairo’s trees.

articles.headline: What China’s Economic Woes May Mean for the U.S.
articles.snippet: The fallout is probably limited — and there may be some upside for American interests.
articles.abstract: The fallout is probably limited — and there may be some upside for American interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news about China’s economy over the past few weeks has been daunting, to put it mildly.

articles.headline: Trump and His Co-Defendants in Georgia Are Already at Odds
articles.snippet: Some defendants have already sought to move the case to federal court, while others are seeking speedy or separate trials.
articles.abstract: Some defendants have already sought to move the case to federal court, while others are seeking speedy or separate trials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as former President Donald J. Trump and his 18 co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case turned themselves in one by one at an Atlanta jail this week, their lawyers began working to change how the case will play out.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: At This Movie, Their Phones Won’t Bother You. Their Barking Might.
articles.snippet: A cinema chain in Britain is welcoming dogs to select screenings. They don’t need their own tickets, and they don’t need to turn off their cellphones.
articles.abstract: A cinema chain in Britain is welcoming dogs to select screenings. They don’t need their own tickets, and they don’t need to turn off their cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kab, a 2-year-old Doberman wearing a blue bandanna, is noticeably anxious.

articles.headline: As Obscure as an Extra, She Has a Lead Role in Hollywood’s Labor Fight
articles.snippet: Carol Lombardini, the studio voice in union talks, values a low profile. That hasn’t kept striking writers and actors from casting her as a villain.
articles.abstract: Carol Lombardini, the studio voice in union talks, values a low profile. That hasn’t kept striking writers and actors from casting her as a villain.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Hollywood union strikes have dragged on, key characters have taken turns in the spotlight.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin

articles.headline: A.I. Brings the Robot Wingman to Aerial Combat
articles.snippet: An Air Force program shows how the Pentagon is starting to embrace the potential of a rapidly emerging technology, with far-reaching implications for war-fighting tactics, military culture and the defense industry.
articles.abstract: An Air Force program shows how the Pentagon is starting to embrace the potential of a rapidly emerging technology, with far-reaching implications for war-fighting tactics, military culture and the defense industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is powered into flight by a rocket engine. It can fly a distance equal to the width of China. It has a stealthy design and is capable of carrying missiles that can hit enemy targets far beyond its visual range.

articles.headline: A Former French President Gives a Voice to Obstinate Russian Sympathies
articles.snippet: Remarks by Nicolas Sarkozy have raised fears that Europe’s pro-Putin chorus may grow louder as Ukraine’s plodding counteroffensive puts pressure on Western resolve.
articles.abstract: Remarks by Nicolas Sarkozy have raised fears that Europe’s pro-Putin chorus may grow louder as Ukraine’s plodding counteroffensive puts pressure on Western resolve.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nicolas Sarkozy, the former French president, was once known as “Sarko the American” for his love of free markets, freewheeling debate and Elvis. Of late, however, he has appeared more like “Sarko the Russian,” even as President Vladimir V. Putin’s ruthlessness appears more evident than ever.

articles.headline: In a Place Shattered by War and Earthquakes, People Feel Forgotten
articles.snippet: In northwestern Syria, a devastating quake six months ago compounded the damage of years of civil war. U.S. lawmakers just visited for the first time in a decade.
articles.abstract: In northwestern Syria, a devastating quake six months ago compounded the damage of years of civil war. U.S. lawmakers just visited for the first time in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the spot where a three-story building completely collapsed after a devastating earthquake struck northwestern Syria in February, a small tent encampment has sprung up. Residents call it “the camp of the forgotten.”
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim and Nicole Tung

articles.headline: Leaderless and Exposed, Russia’s Wagner Faces an Uncertain Future
articles.snippet: It could be hard for the Kremlin to find a way to neutralize the mercenary group after Yevgeny Prigozhin’s death while retaining its fighting power and geopolitical links.
articles.abstract: It could be hard for the Kremlin to find a way to neutralize the mercenary group after Yevgeny Prigozhin’s death while retaining its fighting power and geopolitical links.
articles.lead_paragraph: Its leader is officially dead, as is its founding commander. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is claiming it doesn’t exist.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne and Valerie Hopkins

articles.headline: They’re Forced to Run Online Scams. Their Captors Are Untouchable.
articles.snippet: Gangs in Cambodia have compelled thousands of captives to defraud unsuspecting victims. Because of political connections, no one is stopping them.
articles.abstract: Gangs in Cambodia have compelled thousands of captives to defraud unsuspecting victims. Because of political connections, no one is stopping them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around the world, reports of cyberscam schemes targeting unsuspecting victims online have proliferated rapidly. Southeast Asia has become a center of gravity for those criminal syndicates, often in remote and war-torn corners. But in Cambodia, the scam industry has been flourishing well within the reach of officials.

articles.headline: Electric Vehicle Charging Can Be Confusing. Here’s What to Know.
articles.snippet: Many carmakers and charging companies are switching to the Tesla plug for electric vehicles. Why are they doing that, and what will it mean?
articles.abstract: Many carmakers and charging companies are switching to the Tesla plug for electric vehicles. Why are they doing that, and what will it mean?
articles.lead_paragraph: With a push from Congress, automakers and charging companies are planning to install tens of thousands of fast chargers on American highways capable of refueling electric cars in half an hour or less.

articles.headline: Not Over Yet: Late-Summer Covid Wave Brings Warning of More to Come
articles.snippet: Hospitalizations are still low but have been rising in recent weeks, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
articles.abstract: Hospitalizations are still low but have been rising in recent weeks, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
articles.lead_paragraph: A late-summer wave of coronavirus infections has touched schools, workplaces and local government, as experts warn the public to brace for even more Covid-19 spread this fall and winter.

articles.headline: Judge Sets Trial Date in March for Trump’s Federal Election Case
articles.snippet: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan rejected efforts by the former president’s legal team to postpone the trial until 2026.
articles.abstract: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan rejected efforts by the former president’s legal team to postpone the trial until 2026.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday set a trial date of March 4 in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, rebuffing Mr. Trump’s proposal to push it off until 2026.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
